articles.headline: Financial Crisis Suit Suggests Bad Behavior at Morgan Stanley
articles.snippet: Documents released as part of a lawsuit against Morgan Stanley shed new light on what bankers knew at the height of the housing bubble and what they did with that secret knowledge.
articles.abstract: Documents released as part of a lawsuit against Morgan Stanley shed new light on what bankers knew at the height of the housing bubble and what they did with that secret knowledge.
articles.lead_paragraph: On March 16, 2007, Morgan Stanley employees working on one of the toxic assets that helped blow up the world economy discussed what to name it. Among the team members’ suggestions: “Subprime Meltdown,” “Hitman,” “Nuclear Holocaust” and “Mike Tyson’s Punchout,” as well a simple yet direct reference to a bag of excrement.

articles.headline: House Vote Sidesteps an Ultimatum on Debt
articles.snippet: The move staves off an impasse that could have been disastrous, but an economic showdown with the president is still looming.
articles.abstract: The move staves off an impasse that could have been disastrous, but an economic showdown with the president is still looming.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Avoiding an economic showdown with President Obama, the House on Wednesday passed legislation to eliminate the nation’s statutory borrowing limit until May, without including the dollar-for-dollar spending cuts that Republicans once insisted would have to be part of any debt limit bill.

articles.headline: Pentagon Is Set to Lift Combat Ban for Women
articles.snippet: The groundbreaking decision overturns a 1994 Pentagon rule that restricts women from artillery, armor, infantry and other such combat roles.
articles.abstract: The groundbreaking decision overturns a 1994 Pentagon rule that restricts women from artillery, armor, infantry and other such combat roles.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Leon E. Panetta is lifting the military’s official ban on women in combat, which will open up hundreds of thousands of additional front-line jobs to them, senior defense officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: A Resurgent Netflix Beats Projections, Even Its Own
articles.snippet: Netflix reported $8 million in net income and a jump in the number of subscribers for its streaming service. Analysts were surprised, and investors jumped, sending its shares up 37 percent in Thursday trading.
articles.abstract: Netflix reported $8 million in net income and a jump in the number of subscribers for its streaming service. Analysts were surprised, and investors jumped, sending its shares up 37 percent in Thursday trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: 1:51 p.m. | Updated For all those who have doubted its business acumen, Netflix had a resounding answer on Wednesday: 27.15 million.

articles.headline: Heady Returns, but Apple Finds Its Stock Falling
articles.snippet: Investors have come to expect nothing short of perfection from Apple, but with the company’s stock sinking 11 percent, it is clear there are a range of challenges.
articles.abstract: Investors have come to expect nothing short of perfection from Apple, but with the company’s stock sinking 11 percent, it is clear there are a range of challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple on Wednesday reported the kind of quarter most big companies would envy, posting a profit of $13.1 billion and selling 28 percent more iPhones and 48 percent more iPads, its two biggest products.

articles.headline: Robot Makers Spread Global Gospel of Automation
articles.snippet: Manufacturers of robots and similar machines gathered in Chicago, casting automation as an indispensable engine of economic growth.
articles.abstract: Manufacturers of robots and similar machines gathered in Chicago, casting automation as an indispensable engine of economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The robot equipment industry has one word for the alarmist articles and television news programs that predict a robot is about to steal your job: Fiddlesticks!

articles.headline: Democrats in Senate Confront Doubts at Home on Gun Laws
articles.snippet: Several Democratic senators up for re-election next year are confronting galvanized constituencies that view any effort to tighten gun laws as an infringement.
articles.abstract: Several Democratic senators up for re-election next year are confronting galvanized constituencies that view any effort to tighten gun laws as an infringement.
articles.lead_paragraph: BECKLEY, W.Va. — Talk of stricter gun control has stirred up a lot of unease here, a place where hunters vie for top prize (a 26-inch LED television) in the Big Buck Photo Contest, and ads for a gun-simulator game ask, “Feel like shooting something today?”

articles.headline: A Signal to Wall Street In Obama’s Pick For Regulators
articles.snippet: The White House took the unusual step of choosing two former prosecutors as top financial regulators. But translating that resolve into action will not be easy, given the complexities of the market and Wall Street’s aggressive nature.
articles.abstract: The White House took the unusual step of choosing two former prosecutors as top financial regulators. But translating that resolve into action will not be easy, given the complexities of the market and Wall Street’s aggressive nature.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Benjamin Weiser
